info:
This guide is like a tour of the Internet. As you follow along, you’ll find links to a variety of resources that real-world developers use. In particular, you’ll find tons of links to MDN and W3Schools, two sites dedicated to documenting how web code works. While MDN usually provides more up-to-date information, W3Schools offers a friendlier interface. Together, the sites cover everything you need to know to make your own websites.

Additionally, you’ll find GD with GD links scattered throughout this guide. These include coding demos (via DEMOLAND) to help tie concepts together and exercises (via test-projct-1.html) to put said concepts in use.

resources.title: MDN
resources.desc: Web code documentation (more up-to-date, but sometimes overwhelming)

resources.title: W3Schools
resources.desc: Web code documentation (less up-to-date, but friendlier)

resources.title: DEMOLAND
resources.desc: In-browser editor for viewing code demos

info:
A website is an HTML (or .html) file. What does that mean?

Code is just text stored in a file. We call this plaintext, because it doesn’t have any associated design (like font or color). Instead, it’s just text. The way we can tell programming languages apart is by their syntax, or their rules. HTML’s main rule is that we separate information by writing HTML elements.

This means that HTML doesn’t care that much about tabs, spaces, or line breaks. We’ll still use them, but mainly to organize our code. To get around this, we’ll need to use HTML elements.

resources.title: HTML (HyperText Markup Language)
resources.desc: The main programming language for the web

resources.title: HTML Elements
resources.desc: A piece of content on a website (text, images, metadata, etc.)

resources.title: HTML Comments
resources.desc: Notes written into an HTML file

resources.title: <head> _ </head>
resources.desc: Invisible metadata relating to your website

resources.title: <title> _ </title>
resources.desc: The title that appears in your browser tab

resources.title: <body> _ </body>
resources.desc: The visible content on your site

info:
We can think of HTML as the content on your website. There are different kinds of content, but the most basic kind is text. HTML handles text via several dedicated HTML elements, from paragraphs to headings to lists and more. Each of these elements comes with its own set of default styles (which we will soon be able to override). For now, let’s make a website that actually says something!

Note: this is NOT a complete list of HTML elements! These are just the most common elements you’ll encounter for typography.

resources.title: Typographic Hierarchy
resources.desc: Example of how you might code a basic webpage

resources.title: HTML Entities
resources.desc: Special codes for specific characters you can’t type otherwise (like the < symbol)

resources.title: HTML Text Fundamentals
resources.desc: Deep dive into typography on the web

info:
There’s not much you can do with just HTML. To start making your website pretty, we’ll need to use CSS. CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is another programming language that works with HTML to style HTML elements.

CSS mainly uses two things: properties and classes. Properties define the different visual characteristics of HTML elements, while classes organize sets of properties so that you can apply all of them at once wherever you want. We can even embed CSS right into an HTML element’s opening tag!

resources.title: <style> _ </style>
resources.desc: Element for writing CSS in an HTML document

resources.title: .class-name { color: red; font-size: 12px; }
resources.desc: CSS classes (applying CSS to multiple HTML elements)

resources.title: style="color: red; font-size: 12px;"
resources.desc: Inline CSS (applying CSS to a single HTML element)

resources.title: <span> _ </span>
resources.desc: Inline text element (for adding CSS to specific words)

resources.title: Baby Steps
resources.desc: Everything you need to know to launch a website

resources.title: Web-safe Fonts
resources.desc: Fonts that are available on (nearly) every computer

resources.title: font-weight: 500;
resources.desc: Specify a font’s weight (or range of weights for variable fonts, e.g. 100 900)

resources.title: font-variation-settings: "wght" 500, "SRFF" 0;
resources.desc: Setting values for variable font axes

resources.title: font-feature-settings: "wght" 500, "SRFF" 0;
resources.desc: Turning on or off OpenType features for your font

resources.title: * { _ }
resources.desc: Universal selector (apply CSS to every HTML element

resources.title: display: block;
resources.desc: Set an element to block, inline, inline-block, or none (we’ll have more options later!)

resources.title: scroll-behavior: smooth;
resources.desc: CSS property for smoothly scrolling when clicking an anchor link

info: What does it mean for a website to be responsive? For starters, it means that no matter your screen size, the site should adjust its layout keep a good user experience.

resources.title: An Interactive Guide to CSS Grid
